0.00.text:
Translator: Ellen Maloney
Reviewer: Mile Živković

11.50.text: This talk I'm giving now is entitled

14.28.text:
"The Power of Podcasting:
from Jesus Christ to Andy Zaltzman."

21.24.text:
You've probably heard
of Jesus Christ already,

25.38.text: for those of you who've not heard of him,

27.34.text:
prominent, turn-of-the-first-millennium,
middle-east based magician, and raconteur.

33.55.text:
Which I will admit is a slightly Jewish
angle on the subject,

38.36.text: but I am slightly Jewish so it's fine.

41.00.text:
I'm a second-generation
lapsed Jew, and as you know,

43.95.text:
lapsedness comes down
through the father,

45.88.text:
Jewishness through the mother,
and they sort of cancel each other out.

49.22.text:
It means I'm neutral on Jesus
but I know all the loopholes.

51.98.text:
For example, I know bacon
is kosher if you eat it ironically.

59.38.text: It's all about the look in your eye.

62.91.text:
I was born Jewish and slightly
brought up Jewish,

65.93.text:
but I don't have that much
Judaism left in me.

69.50.text:
The only real legacy
of my Jewish heritage that I have,

72.79.text:
which I've had ever since
I was a small child,

75.03.text:
is a life-long fear of people attacking
the end of my penis with a sharp blade.

79.97.text: I don't know why that is.

82.41.text:
You've heard of Jesus,
let me introduce myself.

84.65.text: I'm Andy Zaltzman, I'm a comedian.

89.87.text:
There's still a court case from a gig
I did in Leeds about ten years ago.

94.82.text:
I'm a three-time European
classical air-guitar champion,

100.77.text:
in the British National Silver Medal
Winning Championships.

105.21.text: A performance I was delighted by.

110.64.text:
And I do this podcast
called "The Bugle" with John Oliver,

114.54.text:
who you probably know
from The Daily Show in The States,

120.77.text:
Podcasting has been
a big part of my career

122.79.text: for the last six - seven years,

125.80.text:
and therefore, I consider podcasting
the only valid art form left on Earth.

131.73.text:
By which I mean
it is largely unsullied by money.

135.75.text: I've done all kinds of podcasts.

137.28.text:
I've done comedy podcasts,
I've done cricket podcasts,

140.54.text:
I know far too much about cricket,
I prefer cricket to reality.

145.86.text:
Even on one occasion,
I took part in a science podcast.

151.10.text:
Me and science are very much
uneasy bedfellows.

154.70.text: To be honest, my attitude towards science

156.67.text:
is if it wasn't in the GCSE syllabus
in 1990, it probably isn't worth knowing.

162.46.text:
If you doubt me, A) gravity still works
much the same as it did back then,

167.13.text:
and B) how much top-end physics
has Albert Einstein done since 1990?

172.71.text:
I did do a few scientific
experiments in my day.

175.00.text:
I found out a shaved dog is angrier
than an unshaven dog.

180.32.text: Found that out the hard way,

181.72.text:
and also discovered
that an agnostic child,

183.73.text:
if you throw it at a church wall,
rebounds at increased velocity.

190.82.text:
The history of podcasting, it goes back
deep into the midst of time.

194.50.text:
Well, ten years frankly, but it could have
gone back deep into the midst of time

199.24.text:
and it makes me think how different
history could have been with podcasting.

205.26.text:
You don't need to be a rocket historian
to work that one out.

208.88.text:
You think back, there were seeds
of podcasting throughout history.

212.54.text:
Town criers in Britain, very much
the podcasters of their day,

216.52.text:
with episodes such as "What To Do
If You've Got The Plague,"

220.63.text:
"Why You're Living In A Mud Hut
Whilst Your Boss Is In A Massive Castle,"

227.06.text:
Homer, the pro-celebrity
ancient Greek, epic poet,

230.55.text:
very much I consider him
a podcaster of his day

233.80.text:
in the oral tradition of passing down
stories through generations.

237.36.text: Arguably, having studied it at university,

239.37.text:
it might have been better
if he'd done it in weekly chunks per week

242.54.text:
rather than the whole lot taking
three days sitting around a campfire.

248.49.text:
To me that's where the form
of communication originated.

252.68.text:
Running around shouting,
"Look out, there's a dinosaur,"

255.36.text:
and, "Raquel Welch
looks phenomenal in a bikini!"

259.06.text:
That was some form of primeval
podcasting, if only they'd known it.

265.91.text:
which admittedly, wasn't quite
such a pejorative term at the time.

269.19.text:
In many ways, it was quite de rigueur
to have those attitudes then,

272.39.text:
but how much faster
would they have evolved

274.52.text:
if they had been able
to share their ideas globally

278.49.text:
and tell each other
which berries not to eat?

281.63.text:
The ancient Romans,
if they put out podcasts,

283.73.text:
explaining how impressive
their engineering was,

285.97.text:
maybe Alarik the Visigoth's stag night
wouldn't have gotten so out of hand.

289.49.text:
They would have been more interested
in what the Romans could offer them.

292.92.text:
Podcasting was actually predicted
as a form of global communication

296.13.text:
exactly 100 years ago, by a man
called Professor Redhorn Snouterback.

302.13.text:
In this book that I managed
to pick up a copy of,

308.08.text:
in which he predicted various things
that would happen 100 years from now.

311.84.text: It's amazing how accurate he got it.

314.04.text: He predicted the podcast; he said,

315.89.text:
"People would be able to think
something interesting, speak it out loud,

319.27.text:
and be heard by people
all around the world."

322.86.text:
Just the mechanism he got wrong,
thought it would be a giant ear trumpet.

328.06.text:
He also predicted
that footballers would be paid

333.70.text:
because they would have become
600 times as useful.

336.50.text:
He predicted we would have a tattoo
industry in Britain

339.10.text:
worth more than the entire
manufacturing sector put together,

346.30.text:
It's amazing the explosion of tattoos
when you think just a generation ago,

349.82.text:
parents still had the ability to remember
the names of all of their children -

355.74.text:
without having them
indelibly inscribed on their arms.

364.13.text: He also predicted an economic downturn

367.74.text:
a multi-million industry
based around pubic topiary.

371.93.text:
He also predicted,
and this was crucial to the podcast,

375.69.text:
a single pocket device
which would incorporate

377.97.text:
the telephone, the telegraph,
the wireless, the gramophone,

380.74.text:
the diary, secretary, the wife,
the mistress, gentlemen's club,

383.85.text:
and the tradition of trying
to knock down buildings

388.74.text: He was very much a man ahead of his time.

391.61.text:
He also predicted the England cricket team
would drop their batsman for being a dick.

404.02.text: It made me think about Jesus.

405.85.text:
Basically, how much would his career
have benefited from podcasts?

411.36.text:
I think the internet would have 
changed his career.

413.82.text:
There would have been various
hashtag campaigns

426.68.text:
But if he came back today, and I realise
that is from a lapsed Jewish perspective,

434.19.text:
probably the biggest if
since Rudyard Kipling

436.31.text:
started projecting the titles of his poems
onto the night skies above Gotham City.

440.75.text: If he did come back to life, for a start,

443.39.text:
he'd have trouble persuading social media
that he was the real deal.

447.67.text:
They'd probably just tell him
that his beard looked stupid,

450.52.text: and where to stick his mother.

453.34.text: If he came back today for a second start,

455.53.text:
he would almost certainly ride
a Harley Davidson instead of a donkey.

461.83.text: He'd probably invest in a decent lawyer,

463.96.text:
rather than representing
himself at court cases,

467.42.text: and I think, he would be a podcaster.

469.55.text:
Jesus Christ would do podcasts, sometimes
on his own, cranking out a parable,

473.55.text:
sometimes with his disciples,
just chewing the cud,

477.89.text:
and sometimes in interview
with someone he'd saved.

480.19.text:
You know, "So Lazarus, exactly
what did your missus say

482.80.text:
when you walked back in
and demanded dinner?"

486.59.text:
Parables were very much the podcast
of their day, and it was that

489.64.text: that helped Jesus go slowly viral,

495.09.text: to the start of the first millennium.

497.31.text:
Why would he use podcasts rather than
other forms such as Youtube?

500.59.text: Well, Youtube, I don't think it's as good.

502.84.text:
It's too easy to flip from one
Messiah to the other,

505.91.text:
depending on the epic-ness
of their miracles.

508.29.text:
And also get distracted by videos of a dog
falling off a skateboard.

513.27.text:
That shows the difference
between Youtube and podcasts,

515.87.text:
audio of a dog falling off a skateboard -
much less interesting than the video.

524.75.text: Why would he not use television?

526.85.text:
Well there's always editorial
compromise and you just know

529.56.text:
the producers will want him to put
more sex and violence in his parables.

533.36.text:
Radio, too slow; the commissioning
process takes too long.

536.62.text:
Should be a medium that can react
instantly to events

539.31.text:
but the way Radio Four
commissioning process works,

541.85.text:
George Formby would still
be waiting for clearance

544.20.text:
to do a show about the Munich
peace talks of 1938,

547.86.text:
including an amusing song
about where Neville Chamberlain

550.72.text: might end up using that piece of paper.

555.19.text:
I think the podcast would give Jesus
a number of great creative opportunities

562.34.text: this form of broadcasting to everyone.

564.99.text: You don't need to wait to do something.

567.01.text:
You have an idea, put it out there,
and within minutes, it's being listened to

571.20.text:
by seven billion people
around the world.

575.13.text:
I mean, clearly, that is very much
a two-edged banana of opportunity.

578.76.text:
You have to make sure you have
the right end in your mouth,

581.52.text: and the right end in your hand,

583.06.text:
not just jabbing yourself in the face
with one spiky end in each eye.

588.02.text:
Before that thing collapses
like an overstretched metaphor.

591.84.text:
History is littered with people
whose messages would have been better

597.39.text: and podcasts do have an independence.

600.88.text:
They're cheap to make,
and they're quick to make.

603.88.text:
It also provides you
with a creative blank canvas

606.53.text: which is a wonderful thing, certainly,

608.46.text: as a comedian, to have that total freedom

611.08.text: to do whatever we want in the show.

612.97.text:
Now admittedly, not all blank canvases
end up with a Mona Lisa on them.

617.28.text:
Some end up looking like Jackson Pollock
has just vomited into a jet-engine,

621.31.text: if my kids' artwork is anything to go by.

626.64.text:
Well actually, to be honest,
no, it does not look like a doggy.

630.19.text:
You're six years old, my trainer
was made by someone in your peer group.

644.51.text:
If there's a show you've always wanted,
you can just make it.

647.66.text:
If you've always wanted to listen
to Alan Titchmarsh's Farmageddon Show

651.33.text:
about how to be self-sufficient
after a nuclear holocaust,

654.15.text:
you don't have to sit waiting
for the BBC to ring up

656.67.text: and ask you to do it.

657.69.text: Now you can just go out, and make it.

659.86.text:
It's no longer a pipe dream, you can light
that pipe dream and smoke it,

663.31.text:
assuming that you can persuade
Alan Titchmarsh to do the show,

666.30.text: or pay for a Titchmarsh impersonator,

668.38.text:
or kidnap Titchmarsh
and force him to do it.

670.43.text:
That's pretty much the way the BBC
has always worked with him.

674.41.text:
He actually hates gardening
but fears moths.

677.72.text:
They just keep him next to a giant moth
in the BBC building.

680.63.text:
Also, with a podcast,
it gives you a chance to reach

685.63.text:
Much of mainstream culture
is a process of compromise.

689.87.text:
You might think a lot
of mainstream popular culture

692.54.text:
is very much like staring
into an abyss of nothingness,

695.11.text: able to hear nothing and see nothing,

697.41.text:
apart from the distant echo
of civilization's past asking, "Why?"

702.06.text:
Did our grandparents really slam-dunk
Hitler into the wheelie-bin of history

705.70.text: so we could watch unending Karaoke

708.00.text:
and medium-quality dancing
until we'd all died inside.

712.67.text:
But the internet has now opened up
the creative opportunities for anyone.

716.47.text: We have shows that aim creatively high,

720.01.text: that cater for specialist niche interests.

722.38.text:
Now you can listen
to great shows about science,

725.00.text:
reading great literature
shows with with cultural insights,

728.02.text:
comedy shows untrammeled
by broadcasters restrictions,

730.59.text:
you can now listen
to a woman in South Dakota

733.20.text:
telling you about the history
of the bicycle pump,

735.73.text:
or Stephen Hawking and Cheryl Cole
discussing with each other

738.92.text:
their favorite bits
of science and music respectively.

741.76.text:
Or three teenagers somewhere in Burundi
with an hour-long broadcast

745.74.text:
about how Arsène Wenger has to go 
if Arsenel ever want to challenge

750.72.text:
It's brought the world together
with this community of values.

753.64.text:
None of those podcasts actually exist,
but the point is they could exist,

757.65.text:
and in many ways, that is more important
than them actually existing.

767.00.text:
and you've got committed
listenership with a podcast,

769.51.text:
which is why I think Jesus
would have loved this format.

772.77.text:
Committed listenership; it's basically
what he relied on as his business M.O.

778.42.text: Because when you listen to a podcast,

780.33.text:
it's not like listening to the radio,
you actively download it.

784.20.text:
You actively listen to it,
and concentrate on listening to it.

788.23.text: And listen to it in extraordinary places.

790.21.text:
We've had emails in to The Bugle
from people listening

792.75.text: whilst doing some of the following:

797.91.text:
- I don't know if that works
as a technical painkiller or not -

801.33.text:
working for an aid agency in Darfur, 
having a vasectomy, and being in Uruguay.

809.44.text:
I think that would be very good
to help Jesus spread his message

812.61.text:
to people having vasectomies
in Uruguay whilst giving birth.

816.33.text: That's probably a bit of a niche market.

819.54.text:
But also, people don't listen
properly to the radio.

826.89.text:
If you ever make it
to the end of a travel bulletin,

831.88.text: they realize no one is listening and say,

833.98.text:
"Careful on the M6,
there's an escaped bison,

836.07.text:
dressed as Ned Kelly,
armed with a water pistol.

838.32.text:
And Debbie,
if you're listening, screw you!"

841.27.text:
It helps as a listener,
you can take advantage of dead time

844.80.text:
such as those hours wasted
having repeated vasectomies.

848.51.text:
This is why I think Jesus very much
would have been

852.31.text: a prime podcaster of his day,

856.98.text: and like many things on the internet,

858.74.text:
it's provided a melting pot
of ideas and creativity,

861.65.text:
unfettered, depending
on where you live, clearly.

863.95.text:
A platform for the exchange 
of high-end concepts, stories,

866.71.text:
philosophies, culture, information, jokes,
outright bullshit, and contrived puns.

870.79.text:
Mostly, in my case,
the last three categories.

873.97.text:
Jesus might have operated
toward the other end

878.63.text:
but I think we'd have been
in the same playground.
